data.title: 24 Best Agile Software Development Tools Of 2024
data.meta_description: The best agile software development tools. Ride the wave of modern software development and revolutionize your digital output today.
data.text:
After a thorough evaluation, I've curated the best agile software development tools in this shortlist, with some more options below:

Yodiz - Best for the integrated issue and bug tracking

Taiga - Best for customization and user-friendly experience

Axosoft - Best for comprehensive release planning

Pivotal Tracker - Best for visibility and collaboration

GitLab - Best for continuous integration and delivery

Zoho Sprints - Best for scrum framework adoption

Asana - Best for task management and tracking

Monday.com - Best for workflow automation

Trello - Best for Kanban project management

ClickUp - Best for diverse project view options

Jira - Best for large-scale agile projects

Smartsheet - Best for real-time collaboration and reporting

Navigating the world of Agile project management software can seem daunting. From comprehensive dashboards to interactive roadmaps, these tools are packed with features designed to streamline your software development projects.

As someone who's worked in the thick of Agile management, I understand the necessity of a robust project management solution. The right tool can enable effortless sprint planning, offer insightful burndown charts, and foster teamwork with features like file sharing and drag-and-drop dependencies management.

These tools are not just about managing subtasks and setting due dates; they're about enhancing collaboration, keeping stakeholders in the loop, and making sure nothing falls through the cracks. Be it backlog management, resource management, or just providing pre-built templates, a user-friendly interface is key to cater to every use case.

Your ideal tool should make you feel in control, not overwhelmed. Trust me, once you experience how these tools can change your agile processes, you'll wonder how you managed without them.

What is an Agile Software Development Tool?

Agile software development tools are specialized applications used by development teams to apply agile methodologies in their projects. These methodologies, including Scrum, Kanban, and others, emphasize adaptability, continuous improvement, and customer satisfaction. The tools are designed to facilitate these principles, offering features for project planning, task management, collaboration, and tracking progress.

Users range from software developers and project managers to business analysts and product owners. These tools prove crucial in planning sprints, managing backlogs, tracking bugs, fostering team communication, and visualizing progress, thereby aligning the development process with business goals and customer needs.

1. Yodiz - Best for integrated issue and bug tracking

Yodiz is a comprehensive agile project management tool equipped with robust features. It particularly stands out for its integrated issue and bug-tracking capabilities, providing a streamlined platform to handle all kinds of development obstacles.

Why I Picked Yodiz:

In my careful selection process, I singled out Yodiz due to its comprehensive approach to agile software development. What makes Yodiz different is its emphasis on simplicity, coupled with depth in features. I determined that Yodiz is best for integrated issue and bug tracking as it offers an efficient, all-in-one platform to manage, prioritize, and solve development issues.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Yodiz flaunts an intuitive Scrum board, issue tracker, and Epics & Stories management. The agile reporting tools with real-time metrics offer valuable insight into the project's progress. Yodiz also integrates with leading platforms such as Slack, GitHub, Jenkins, and many more, reinforcing its capability as a versatile project management tool.

Pricing:

Yodiz pricing starts from $3/user/month, making it a budget-friendly solution for teams of all sizes. Do note that this is the cost for their starter pack which is billed annually.

Pros:

Efficient issue and bug tracking

Easy-to-use Scrum board

Comprehensive reporting tools

Cons:

Lacks advanced customization options

Interface can be complex for beginners

Customer support needs improvement

2. Taiga - Best for customization and user-friendly experience

Taiga is a project management platform with a user-friendly interface and extensive customization options. It is designed to streamline project tracking, which, in tandem with its ability to be tailored to unique project needs, makes it particularly effective for teams seeking a user-friendly, adaptable tool.

Why I Picked Taiga:

As I compared several tools, Taiga grabbed my attention with its visually appealing and intuitive interface. What sets Taiga apart from the crowd is its dedication to providing a customizable user experience without compromising usability. The balance it strikes between adaptability and ease of use is the reason I chose it as the best for customization and a user-friendly experience.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Taiga's standout features include a multi-project workspace, sprints, user stories, and Kanban boards, allowing for an in-depth, flexible project management approach. Its integrations include GitHub, Slack, and Trello, among others, which help bridge workflows and consolidate work processes.

Pricing:

The pricing for Taiga starts from $5/user/month, making it accessible for teams of all sizes. This price point is for their standard plan, and it is billed annually.

Pros:

Customizable and user-friendly

Supports multiple project workspaces

Wide array of integrations

Cons:

Advanced features locked behind higher tiers

Customer support could be faster

Limited built-in reporting options

3. Axosoft - Best for comprehensive release planning

Axosoft is a powerful tool that offers a suite of agile project management capabilities. With a particular focus on release planning, Axosoft gives teams the ability to anticipate, plan, and execute software launches with precision and ease.

Why I Picked Axosoft:

When weighing the contenders, Axosoft impressed me with its strong emphasis on release planning. The platform stands out with its comprehensive approach to managing software releases, which is often an area overlooked by other tools. That’s why I chose Axosoft as the best tool for comprehensive release planning.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Key features of Axosoft include release planning, scrum project management, incident tracking, and robust analytics. It provides integrations with popular platforms such as GitHub, Slack, Trello, and more, creating a unified workspace that caters to diverse development needs.

Pricing:

Axosoft starts at $12/user/month, billed annually. This price is for their basic plan to provide teams with a comprehensive yet affordable solution.

Pros:

Focused on comprehensive release planning

Offers a robust set of project management features

Provides integrations with popular platforms

Cons:

Steeper learning curve for beginners

Pricing can be high for small teams

Interface could be more modern

4. Pivotal Tracker - Best for visibility and collaboration

Pivotal Tracker, a purpose-built tool, simplifies complex software projects with its unique combination of functionality. It fosters visibility and collaboration, making it the perfect partner for teams that want to keep everyone on the same page.

Why I Picked Pivotal Tracker:

In comparing numerous tools, I selected Pivotal Tracker for its distinct ability to enhance visibility and foster collaboration. Its functionality promotes full project transparency and encourages team interaction. Therefore, it stands as the best for teams seeking a collaborative work environment with clear visibility.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Pivotal Tracker's standout features include shared project state, notifications, and fine-grained permissions for team collaboration. It also integrates with tools like Slack, Jira, and GitHub, augmenting its capacity to create an easy work environment.

Pricing:

Pricing starts from $6.50/user/month for the Pivotal Tracker's paid plans, providing a cost-effective solution for teams of all sizes.

Pros:

Provides high visibility and fosters collaboration

Offers fine-grained permissions for better control

Integrates with popular development tools

Cons:

Interface might be complex for new users

Some users may find the workflow rigid

Could offer more comprehensive reporting tools

5. GitLab - Best for continuous integration and delivery

GitLab is a single application for the entire DevOps lifecycle. By offering a comprehensive toolkit for software development, it has notably become a go-to resource for continuous integration and delivery (CI/CD), which makes it particularly powerful for DevOps teams.

Why I Picked GitLab:

I chose GitLab primarily due to its robust capabilities in handling continuous integration and delivery. This tool stands out because of its built-in CI/CD, which minimizes the hassle of setting up and maintaining separate tools or services for these critical processes. Hence, GitLab is my top choice for those prioritizing CI/CD in their development operations.

Standout Features & Integrations:

GitLab's built-in continuous integration, deployment, and delivery, coupled with its comprehensive project and team management tools, make it a versatile choice. It offers a plethora of integrations, with notable ones including Kubernetes for improved deployment, Jira for better project management, and Slack for team communication.

Pricing:

The starting price for GitLab's paid tiers is from $4/user/month, which is an affordable option given its rich features and capabilities.

Pros:

Provides robust continuous integration and delivery features

Comprehensive project and team management tools

Extensive list of integrations for an better workflow

Cons:

Might have a steep learning curve for beginners

Interface can be slow at times

Some advanced features may be overwhelming for small projects

6. Zoho Sprints - Best for scrum framework adoption

Zoho Sprints is an agile project management tool that assists teams in planning, tracking, and releasing software. Its specialty lies in the Scrum framework adoption, which makes it highly useful for teams looking to implement this specific methodology.

Why I Picked Zoho Sprints:

I picked Zoho Sprints due to its clear focus on the Scrum framework. This tool stands out as it provides a set of features tailored specifically for Scrum, such as sprints, backlogs, scrum boards, and velocity charts. Given this, I see Zoho Sprints as the best fit for teams looking to adopt or enhance their use of the Scrum framework.

Standout Features & Integrations:

The standout features of Zoho Sprints include a user-friendly Scrum board for task management, project management methodology, customizable workflows, and detailed reporting options, including velocity charts. It provides integrations with a range of other Zoho tools as well as external platforms such as Slack and Google Suite, facilitating communication and productivity within the project team.

Pricing:

Zoho Sprints pricing starts from $12/user/month when billed annually, offering a fairly priced solution for its robust set of features tailored for Scrum.

Pros:

Scrum-specific features facilitate effective Scrum implementation

Provides a user-friendly and customizable interface

Offers a comprehensive integration with Zoho's suite and external platforms

Cons:

The pricing model may be a bit steep for small teams

Lacks in-depth features for other agile methodologies

Customer support might be a bit slow

7. Asana - Best for task management and tracking

Asana is a project management platform that helps teams organize, track, and manage their work. It stands out particularly for its capabilities in task management and tracking, offering a wide range of features designed to keep every task on schedule and under control.

Why I Picked Asana:

I chose Asana due to its excellent task management and tracking features. Its distinguishing factor is its focus on individual tasks, helping teams break down large projects into manageable pieces. I find Asana to be the best tool for those who require a strong emphasis on task management and tracking within their project lifecycle.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Asana’s standout features include detailed task assignment options, timeline views for tracking progress, and the ability to create custom workflows to match team processes. Asana integrates well with many tools teams commonly use, such as Slack for communication, Google Drive for document management, and GitHub for software development.

Pricing:

Asana's pricing starts from $10.99/user/month when billed annually, making it a reasonably priced choice for its comprehensive task management and tracking features.

Pros:

Robust task management and tracking capabilities

Offers timeline views to track project progress

Integrates well with many commonly used tools

Cons:

Might be slightly complex for beginners

Mobile app experience could be improved

Additional features are available only at higher price tiers

8. Monday.com - Best for workflow automation

Monday.com is a flexible platform that helps teams manage their work and improve productivity. It's particularly strong in workflow automation, enabling businesses to create automated sequences that increase efficiency and reduce manual effort.

Why I Picked Monday.com:

I picked Monday.com because its workflow automation capabilities stood out from other tools. The platform allows users to set up complex automation sequences, effectively removing manual processes and increasing efficiency. I judged Monday.com as the best tool for organizations looking to enhance their workflow automation.

Standout features & integrations:

Monday.com's automation features, like rule-based triggers and custom workflow creation, allow teams to streamline their processes. It offers integrations with a wide array of apps such as Slack, Google Drive, and Microsoft Teams, enabling easy data flow across different platforms.

Pricing:

The pricing for Monday.com starts from $8/user/month (billed annually), making it a competitive choice for its advanced automation capabilities.

Pros:

Strong workflow automation capabilities

A wide range of integrations

Highly customizable

Cons:

The interface might feel overwhelming at first

The mobile app lacks some features of the desktop version

High-end features require more expensive plans

9. Trello - Best for Kanban project management

Trello is a web-based project management tool that uses the Kanban methodology for organizing projects. It provides an intuitive user interface where tasks are represented by cards that can be dragged and dropped across various stages, making it an effective solution for teams practicing Kanban project management.

Why I Picked Trello:

I chose Trello for this list due to its simple yet powerful Kanban management capabilities. The tool's interactive boards, lists, and cards make it stand out and provide an effective way to visually track and manage project progress. In my comparison of project management tools, Trello struck me as the best for teams using the Kanban methodology.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Key features of Trello include customizable Kanban boards, task assignments, deadlines, and labels for better task organization. It also supports various integrations with other popular tools like Slack, Google Drive, and Jira, enabling users to streamline their workflow without leaving the platform.

Pricing:

Trello's pricing starts from $10/user/month (billed annually). This is the cost for their "Business Class" plan as they do have a free tier, but it's more limited in its capabilities.

Pros:

Intuitive and user-friendly interface

Extensive customization options

Offers a wide range of integrations

Cons:

Lack of built-in reporting tools

Can get cluttered with large projects

Advanced features require the paid plan

10. ClickUp - Best for diverse project view options

ClickUp is a cloud-based project management and collaboration tool that suits businesses of all sizes and industries. Its standout feature is the flexibility in project view options, accommodating various work styles and processes.

Why I Picked ClickUp:

I picked ClickUp for its diverse project view options. Users have the freedom to choose from views like list view, board view, box view, Gantt chart, and more, according to their preference or the project's needs. When assessing different project management tools, this diversity of views set ClickUp apart. This versatility led me to judge ClickUp as the best for diverse project view options.

Standout Features & Integrations:

ClickUp's most noteworthy features include task management with the ability to assign comments, goal tracking with targets and milestones, and the already mentioned versatile viewing options. ClickUp also offers integrations with a wide iteration of tools, including but not limited to Slack, Google Calendar, GitHub, and Toggl.

Pricing:

ClickUp's pricing starts at $5/user/month for their "Unlimited" plan. This price point reflects their lowest-tier paid plan, providing more features compared to the free version.

Pros:

Offers multiple project view options

Ability to assign comments as tasks

Wide range of integrations

Cons:

Might have a steep learning curve due to numerous features

Interface may seem cluttered with too many options

Reporting features could be more robust

11. Jira - Best for large-scale agile projects

Jira by Atlassian is a project management tool that is tailored for agile software development. Known for its robustness and scalability, it caters particularly well to large-scale agile projects, providing end-to-end project oversight.

Why I Picked Jira:

I chose Jira because of its powerful capabilities and extensive adaptability in managing complex, large-scale agile projects. Comparing it to other project management tools, Jira's strength lies in its rich set of features tailored to agile methodologies—Scrum, Kanban, or mixed. This led me to judge it as the best choice for handling large-scale agile projects.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Jira offers comprehensive agile functionality, including but not limited to issue and project tracking, agile reporting, and customizable workflows. On top of that, Jira integrates well with many other tools in the Atlassian suite, like Confluence and Bitbucket, and also supports integrations with external tools, such as Slack and GitHub.

Pricing:

Pricing for Jira starts at $7/user/month, representing the lowest-priced tier beyond their free offering. It provides access to more advanced features that are crucial for effective project management.

Pros:

Tailored for agile methodologies

Highly customizable workflows

Wide range of integrations

Cons:

Could be overwhelming for small teams due to its complexity

Interface may not be as intuitive for beginners

Customization requires a learning curve

12. Smartsheet - Best for real-time collaboration and reporting

Smartsheet is a versatile project management tool known for its spreadsheet-like interface that combines the familiarity of traditional spreadsheets with the functionality of a project management system. It shines in facilitating real-time collaboration and providing powerful reporting capabilities.

Why I Picked Smartsheet:

Smartsheet stood out for me due to its unique combination of the familiarity of spreadsheets with the power of project management tools. It’s real-time collaboration capabilities and advanced reporting features set it apart. After a thorough comparison, I judged it to be the most efficient tool for real-time collaboration and detailed reporting.

Standout Features & Integrations:

Smartsheet's key features include real-time collaboration, Gantt charts, Kanban boards, and robust reporting and analytics. It also allows for automatic updates and reminders. In terms of integrations, Smartsheet works smoothly with popular tools such as Microsoft Office 365, Google Workspace, Slack, and Salesforce.

Pricing:

Smartsheet's pricing starts from $14/user/month, which is the starting point for their paid plans beyond the free trial. This tier provides access to a core set of features suitable for small to medium-sized teams.

Pros:

Familiar spreadsheet-like interface

Strong real-time collaboration features

Powerful reporting and analytics

Cons:

Steep learning curve for advanced features

Limited customization options compared to competitors

Pricing can be expensive for larger teams

When choosing project management software, there are certain factors that can significantly influence the effectiveness and suitability of the tool. I've personally tested and researched these tools, and from the plethora of project management platforms available, I've discerned some critical considerations.

Core Functionality

The tool should enable you to:

Manage tasks and project timelines efficiently

Collaborate and communicate within the team easily

Track project progress and generate comprehensive reports

Allocate and manage resources efficiently

Key Features

When comparing project management tools, I focused on these specific features:

Customizability: The tool should allow you to tailor workflows and processes to suit your team's unique needs.

Scalability: The platform should be able to grow with your organization, handling increased complexity and a larger user base over time.

Integration Capabilities: The tool should integrate with other applications your team uses, like email, document management, and CRM software.

Security Measures: Adequate security features are a must to protect sensitive project information.

Usability

For project management tools, the following elements greatly impact usability:

Intuitive Interface: The tool should have a straightforward, intuitive interface that makes it easy to navigate and find necessary features.

Onboarding Support: A robust onboarding program, such as tutorials, guides, and customer support, can greatly assist new users.

User Access Control: The tool needs to allow the easy configuration of role-based access to protect sensitive information and maintain organizational hierarchy.

Mobile Accessibility: A tool that is accessible and fully functional on mobile devices allows team members to stay connected, even when away from their desks.

Agile software development tools come with numerous benefits. They foster better communication and collaboration within the team, allow for real-time tracking and monitoring of project progress, and enable faster and more efficient issue resolution. These tools also provide robust reporting and analytics capabilities to help make data-driven decisions. Lastly, they offer customizable workflows that can be tailored to fit the unique needs of your team and project.

The pricing of agile software development tools varies widely based on their functionalities, number of users, and additional features. Some tools offer a freemium model where basic functionalities are available for free with the option to upgrade to premium features.

Most agile software development tools use a subscription-based pricing model, usually charged per user per month. Some offer tiered pricing plans, where different levels of functionality and features come at different price points. Others use a flat-rate pricing structure where you pay a single price for access to all features.

The typical range of pricing for these tools can be as low as $7 per user per month to as high as several hundreds of dollars per user per month for more advanced, enterprise-level solutions.

Which are the cheapest and most expensive software?

As of my last review, ClickUp is one of the most cost-effective options starting from $5 per user per month, while Jira align is among the more expensive options starting at $20 per user per month.

Yes, there are several free agile software development tools available. Some of these include Trello and Jira, which offer free plans with basic functionalities suitable for small teams or individual use. Remember, these free plans usually come with limitations, and upgrading to a paid plan may be necessary as your team grows or needs more advanced features.

Summary

The best agile software development tool for you depends on your team's specific needs, size, and budget.

Key takeaways:

1. Focus on core functionality that aligns with your project management style. Whether it's Scrum, Kanban, or a hybrid approach, ensure the tool supports your team's workflow.

2. Consider key features that will enhance your team's productivity and communication. This might include real-time collaboration, diverse project view options, or robust reporting tools.

3. Remember to factor in usability and customer support. A user-friendly interface can significantly reduce onboarding time, and responsive customer support can quickly address any issues that arise.

Want More?

I hope this guide has given you a solid starting point in your search for the best agile software development tools. Agility is pivotal in transforming the management of uncertainty in tech projects.
